oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Early photo of Cossitt Library
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Cossitt Library; Front Street; libraries; post office; 1910s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A 1912 photo of the Cossitt library, taken from the south side of the building. A caption reads, "The Cossitt Library prior to its partial demolishment and modern reconstruction as seen today on Front Street. (left) To the right is Memphis Post Office, once the Main office. When expanded the towers were enclosed and later removed to bring the building to its current height."
oai_dc:dc.dc:format: black & white photo with caption, 10 x 8.5 in.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Memphis & Shelby County Room Photograph Collection

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Memphis Appeal on potential library
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: crime; libraries; Memphis Appeal; newspapers; 1850s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1857 clippings from the Memphis Appeal newspaper. Brief entries in the "Town Facts and Fancies" section cover a variety of events and topics: the capture of an accused murderer, thoughts on a public library, a 300-pound green turtle, Mississippi River levels, the organization of a public Library Association, notes from police court, ward boundaries, and more. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "100 Libraries Found In Memphis Survey"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Commercial Appeal; libraries; 1940s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "In 1847, when Memphis was a mud-bound horse and buggy town, a subscription reading room was opened by the Daily Eagle newspaper for the whiskered and full-skirted citizens. -- Today their descendents enjoy more than 100 public, private, and rental book collections, as revealed by the first directory of Memphis and Shelby County libraries ever published. -- The 56-page pamphlet, compiled and edited by Carey M. Moore, head of Cossitt Library's catalog department, is published by the Memphis Library Club, a county-wide organization. Copies are available at Cossitt Library, Jesse Cunningham, librarian, said. -- Libraries listed are hospital, school, music, institutional, art, garden, law, newspaper, religious, club, community center, civic, industrial, health, housing, business, directory, medical, engineering, government, and general collections. -- Full information is given on each library's scope, staff, hours, contents, support, and special collections and equipment. The data was compiled by questionaire."
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Digital Image ©2010, Memphis Public Library & Information Center. All rights reserved. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "New Public Library To Be Opened April 3"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Commercial Appeal; libraries; Main Library; 1950s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Opening ceremonies for the new Memphis Public Library at McLean and Peabody have been set for Sunday afternoon April 3. -- Final touches, arrangement of furniture and shelving of books are in process right now at the $750,000 installation which will be the center of the city's library system. Cossitt Library, at Front and Monroe, will become a reference library. -- Wassell Randolph, president of the city's library board, will be master of ceremonies, and all directors will be present. Mayor Frank Tobey will speak, and Jesse Cunningham, librarian, will formally assume his new and expanded duties. The ceremonies will begin at 3 p.m. -- The Chickasaw Guards will present an American flag on a mounted staff. Memphis Post No. 1, American Legion, will present a Tennessee state flag. -- The library will be open for public inspection from 3 to 6. -- On the following Sunday afternoon, the Mid-South Children's Book Festival, sponsored by the Soroptimist International Club of Memphis, will open at the new building. On April 15, Dr. Frances of television's Ding Dong School will be guest of the festival and of the new library."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Cossitt Library - Drawing
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: art; Cossitt Library; libraries; Penczner, Paul; 1960s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Note by artist: "Cossitt Library" Dedicated in 1893, this red sandstone Romanesque structure with rounded wings and towering turret and gables, was the home of the first public library in Memphis. At the death of Frederick H. Cossitt, his three daughters learned from notes among his papers that he had intended to donate $75,000 for a library. Honoring his wishes and his memory, they gave this amount.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Penczner, Paul
oai_dc:dc.dc:format: black & white drawing, mounted, 5 x 3.75 in.
oai_dc:dc.dc:identifier: #2155C 3496; Memphis - Libraries - Cossitt Library (Paul Penczner) - c. 1966
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Memphis & Shelby County Room Photograph Collection

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Vance Avenue Branch
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: African Americans; Crenshaw Branch; libraries; Vance Avenue Branch;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A composite of two images - children reading inside a library and the exterior of the Vance Avenue Branch. Text: ENJOYING FREE LIBRARY BOOKS -- PRESENT NEGRO PUBLIC LIBRARY -- The Vance Avenue Library, opened in the summer of 1939, serves the purpose of a central library for colored people in the same manner as the Cossitt Library at Front and Monroe serves the white people. From this main library on Vance, it is hoped to extend a network of libraries for negroes.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: 1958-08-16 Correspondence
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: correspondence; libraries; civil rights; desegregation; Cunningham, Jesse; Hall, E. M.; 1950s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: E.M. Hall, a broker of fruits, vegetables and produce wrote this letter to head librarian Jesse Cunningham: "Dear Mr. Cunningham: I have not taken the time to call or write you commending you on your stand on the mixing of the races for Library use. I did call you when this issue was first raised but I did want to tell you again that I did and still do appreciate the stand that you and the Board have taken in the matter. -- I do feel that we must maintain our position and feelings in this and while I have not publicly and actively done my part in the past, I am determined to do whatever small or large that I can in the present and future. -- We have most all sat idley [sic] by, assuring ourselves that such would never happen but it has and is going to more unless we all express ourselves at the polls and at every opportunity. The NAACP and others are pressing harder every day and we must endeavor to resist. -- I am sure that most all White People want the Library facilities maintained as they are and I feel that we should so express ourselves. -- Wishing for you and the Board complete vindication and assuring your of my support, remain -- Yours very truly, E M Hall"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Hall, E. M.
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Digital Image ©2011, Memphis Public Library & Information Center. All rights reserved. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: 1960-11-17 Correspondence
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: correspondence; libraries; civil rights; desegregation; Wallis, C. Lamar; Loeb, Henry; 1960s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Letter from Library Director Lamar Wallis to Mayor Loeb and City Commissioners: "Gentlemen: At its regular meeting today the Memphis Public Library Board of Directors instructed me to ask the City Commission to meet with the Library Board on Monday, November 21, at 11 a.m. in the Cossitt Library auditorium at 33 South Front. -- The purpose of this meeting is to discuss the question of restroom facilities in the various public library buildings. The negro plaintiff in our current lawsuit has refused to withdraw his suit on the basis that the Library Board has not desegregated all of its facilities, namely the toilets. The Library Board is complying with the City building code by maintaining separate toilet facilities for white and colored and would like to have the City Commission's feeling about this matter. Judge Miller has granted a thirty day period for the Library Board to answer the plaintiff. -- Since we have completely desegregated all library services and facilities except the restrooms, there will be no need to discuss any other matters except this one point, and therefore the meeting should not take long. Sincerely yours, C. Lamar Wallis, Director"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Wallis, C. Lamar
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Digital Image ©2011, Memphis Public Library & Information Center. All rights reserved. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: 1960-12-16 Correspondence
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: correspondence; libraries; civil rights; desegregation; Wallis, C. Lamar; Luening, Eugene A.; 1960s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Letter from Library Director Lamar Wallis to Reverend Eugene Luening, president of the Memphis chapter of the Tennessee Council on Human Relations: "Dear Mr. Leuning: Thank you for your letter of December 14 concerning the desegregation of the Public Library's services and facilities. As you have probably read, we are now caught between a City Ordinance requiring separate rest rooms and the NAACP, who want the use of the same facilities throughout the building. This joint use of the same rest room seems to be the most sensitive point in the whole integration picture up to this moment, and I am not at all sure what the outcome will be in the matter of human relations. -- Sine [sic] the City Commission is not willing to repeal the City Ordinance, the Library Board has entered the ordinance as a defense in the NAACP lawsuit against the library. -- If you happen to have on hand any information concerning the use of rest rooms in other southern communities, I shall be pleased to hear about it. Sincerely,"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Wallis, C. Lamar
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Digital Image ©2011, Memphis Public Library & Information Center. All rights reserved. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: 1960-12-14 Correspondence
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: correspondence; libraries; civil rights; desegregation; Wallis, C. Lamar; Luening, Eugene A.; 1960s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Letter from Eugene Luening, president of the local chapter of the Tennessee Council on Human Relations, to Lamar Wallis, director of the Memphis Public Library: "Dear Mr. Wallis: We would like to commend you and the Board of Trustees of the Library for the quiet and effective way in which the facilities of our public library were opened to all our citizens. It is our hope, of course, that all public facilities in the libraries as well as elsewhere will be as peacefully made available to all. -- If we can be of help at any time please call on us. With correspondents in other Tennessee and Southern communities, we may have information available that could be of assistance. Yours Sincerely, Tennessee Council on Human Relations, Memphis & Shelby County Chapter by (Rev.) Eugene A. Luening"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Luening, Eugene A.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: 1958-08-19 Correspondence
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: correspondence; libraries; civil rights; desegregation; Cunningham, Jesse; Hall, E. M.; 1950s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Letter from librarian Jesse Cunningham to E. M. Hall: "Dear Mr. Hall: I remember our conversation had some time ago about library integration, and I appreciate your interest at the time and your additional interest resulting in your nice letter of August 16. The Library Board is definitely committed to the continuance of our policy in the matter which has existed all through the existence of our public library system. Of course, with a Supreme Court like we have in this country most anything can happen. Thank you for your good wishes. Yours sincerely, J. Cunningham."
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Cunningham, Jesse

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: 1961-05-03 Correspondence - Memo
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: correspondence; Wallis, C. Lamar; Randolph, Wassell; libraries; desegregation; Russell, Edward P.; 1960s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Memo from Lamar Wallis to Wassell Randolph: "Dear Mr. Randolph: First I thought I would let this whole matter drop where it was, but after thinking it over I thought I should write the attached letter to show Ed Russell that I have no sympathy with the opposing side in any way. -- I have no idea what prompted him to say what he did this morning, and I am perfectly willing to forget it so long as I get this into the records. Sincerely,"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Wallis, C. Lamar

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: 1961-05-03 Correspondence - Attachment
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: correspondence; Wallis, C. Lamar; Randolph, Wassell; libraries; desegregation; Russell, Edward P.; 1960s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Letter from Lamar Wallis to Mr. Edward P. Russell, Sr. of Canada, Russell and Turner: "Dear Ed: I congratulate you on your astute handling of our case in federal court. With proof that was admittedly weak you maneuvered with admirable skill to avoid an adverse decision. -- I write this letter lest there remain in your mind the faintest doubt that I have been sympathetic with your efforts and those of the Board in the rest room case. If somewhere you got the impression that the case annoyed me or that I felt that the lawyers were merely arguing 'fiddle-dee' and 'fiddle-dum,' I have deep reason to regret it, for such is not the case. -- I think we will all admit that the weight of court decisions against our cause is almost overwhelming, but I have never recommended to the Board that we abandon all resistance. My position is that of carrying out their wishes with cheerful cooperation, and that I shall continue to do. My personal stand on all of these matters is one of moderation, but I have a personal dislike for the methods of the NAACP and am perfectly willing to do battle as the Board directs. -- An anonymous letter from a Negro who opposed the NAACP informed me two years ago that it was being told by supporters of the plaintiff in our case that I cam to Memphis from Richmond expressly to see to the desegregation of the Memphis Public Library. Nothing could be further from the truth. -- My sympathy is with legal resistance, and I assure you that I am at your service so long as the litigation continues. Sincerely yours, C. Lamar Wallis"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Wallis, C. Lamar
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Digital Image ©2011, Memphis Public Library & Information Center. All rights reserved. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: 1960-10-17 Correspondence and Library Card
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: libraries; civil rights; desegregation; McAlpin, Malcolm; 1960s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A letter from Memphis resident Malcolm McAlpin to the Board of Trustees of the Memphis Public Library: "Gentlemen: I am enclosing one vote in favor of making your facilities totally instead of partially Negroid, a consummation which, as far as I am concerned, is already a lamentable reality. -- I am morally certain that a vast majority of your patrons feel as I do but are either too indolent or too hopeless to register a protest. -- Cordially, if indignantly, Malcolm McAlpin." [Mr. McAlpin's library card, torn in half, is enclosed.]

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: 1958-08-21 Correspondence
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: law; libraries; civil rights; desegregation; Turner, Jesse H.; Randolph, Wassell; Armour, Claude A.; City Commission; 1950s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Letter from President [Wassell Randolph] to City Commissioner Claude Armour: "Dear Commissioner Armour: You have read in the newspapers where Jesse H. Turner, Negro, has filed suit against Memphis Public Library in the United States District Court here. At a meeting of the Directors of the library held yesterday a resolution was adopted, copy of which has been sent to the Mayor, requesting the City Commission at its next meeting to direct Mr. Frank Gianotti, City Attorney, and his legal staff to defend this action on behalf of all defendants. We hope that the City Commission will grant this request. -- Cordially yours, President"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: 1958-09-15 Correspondence
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: law; libraries; civil rights; desegregation; Cossitt Library; Cossitt, Frederick H.; Cossitt family; City Commission; Randolph, Wassell; 1950s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A letter from Board President Wassell Randolph to Mayor Edmund Orgill and City Commissioners Claude A. Armour, Stanley Dillard, John T. Dwyer and Henry Loeb. The letter outlines the history of the Memphis Public Library, stating that it is not a city institution and therefore the city attorney should not represent the library in court. It closes by announcing that the library board has selected Edward P. Russell, Larry Creson and John S. Montedonico as the attorneys to represent them in the litigation.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: 1958-09-22 Incident Report
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: libraries; civil rights; desegregation; African Americans; Haley, Mary T.; 1950s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A report submitted by Mary T. Haley on Sept. 29, 1958 about an incident that occurred a week earlier. -- Monday evening, Sept. 22, 1958 Time: approx. 7:30 P.M. -- 4 Negroes, 3 male, 1 female, high school or college age, came into the library at Peabody and McLean. -- They went straight to the Card Catalog, pulled out a drawer and started to check for the information they wanted. -- I walked over from the Return Desk and asked the boy who was checking on one side of the Alcove: May I help you? He said he was looking for a book on the life of Pestalozzi. -- I told him it would be necessary for him to get his books from the Vance Ave. Branch; to make his request to Mrs. Oates and she would get the book for him. -- He asked how long it would take. The reply: usually the day after the request is made. -- He then wanted to know if they could listen to records in the music room. The reply: You know that you cannot use the music room. -- Ques.: Can we take the records out? Ans.: No, you may not. None of the Branches may borrow records, since the Record Collection is set up for borrowers who come to this branch. -- Ques.: The can we browse around. Ans.: No. -- I then approached the other three and asked: -- And what do you want? The girl replied: Flaubert's Madame Bovary. -- To the same question, the next boy replied: Einstein's Out of my Later Years. -- The third boy's reply to this question was that he didn't want a book. -- I told them I would make a note of their requests and if the books were in, send them to the Vance Ave. Branch where they could get them after noon the next day. -- They left the library. -- A week later the books had not been asked for at the Vance Branch. -- Mary T. Haley -- Sept. 29, 1958"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Haley, Mary T.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: 1960-03-21 Correspondence
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: correspondence; libraries; desegregation; Eastman, Bettye S.; 1960s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Addressed to the Board of the Library: "Gentlemen: I hope that it will be possible to continue having segregated facilities for white and colored. -- Of course the continuation of this policy will probably depend on future court rulings - unless there is some way to circumvent them. -- As one who uses library facilities frequently, as do my children, I just wanted to state my personal feelings. -- Yours very truly, (Mrs.) Bettye S. Eastman"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Eastman, Bettye S.
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Digital Image ©2011, Memphis Public Library & Information Center. All rights reserved. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: 1960-03-24 Correspondence
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: correspondence; libraries; desegregation; Eastman, Bettye S.; Wallis, C. Lamar; 1960s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Dear Mrs. Eastman, -- I appreciate your letter expressing your feelings on the question of segregation of the Library. -- At the first opportunity I will present it to the Board of Directors for their information. -- We cannot say at this point just what the outcome will be, but we hope you and your children will continue to use our facilities at all times. -- Sincerely, -- C. Lamar Wallis -- Director"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Wallis, C. Lamar

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: 1958-08-21 Library Board Resolution
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: libraries; civil rights; desegregation; 1950s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A copy of a memo sent from the Library Board President to Mayor Edmund Orgill. The following resolution is attached: "Resolved that the Mayor and the City Commissioners be requested at the next meeting of the City Commission to pass a resolution directing Mr. Frank B. Gianotti and his legal staff to defend for all the defendants the suit of Jesse H. Turner against Wassell Randolph and others, Number 3525 in the United States District Court at Memphis. That the President be directed to convey a copy of this resolution to Mayor Orgill and that all City Commissioners be advised by him of this action."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: 1958-12-09 Vance Branch Statistics
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: libraries; civil rights; desegregation; statistics; Vance Avenue Branch; 1950s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A memo and two attached pages of statistics. "Dear Walter [Chandler]: -- We had the Vance Avenue staff keep a record of the attendance for adults and children during the month of November. Enclosed is a copy of that record. The statistics for the circulation of books has not been received. When we get these records, I shall be glad to send you a copy if you wish it. -- Yours sincerely, J. Cunningham -- Librarian"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: 1958-12-16 Memo and Incident Report
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: libraries; civil rights; desegregation; Cunningham, Jesse; Chandler, Walter; 1950s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A one-page memo preceeds a two-page incident report from Mrs. Langley, assistant in the children's department. "Dear Walter: -- Enclosed is a statement covering an incident in the library at McLean and Peabody yesterday morning, December 15, 1958. This colored woman is Mrs. Nellie Irwin, living at 166 Angelus, the telephone number being BR 5-5916 in the name of R. A. Irwin. I have a very strong feeling that this woman was sent here for the purpose of creating another incident that might be used as evidence in our case. Perhaps our attorneys would like to have it. -- Yours sincerely, -- J. Cunningham -- Librarian"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Cunningham, Jesse
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Digital Image ©2012, Memphis Public Library & Information Center. All rights reserved. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: 1958-08-21 Dwyer Correspondence
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: libraries; civil rights; desegregation; Randolph, Wassell; Dwyer, John T. "Buddy"; 1950s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Copy of a letter sent by Wassell Randolph to Commissioner Dwyer: "Dear Commissioner Dwyer: -- You have read in the newspapers where Jesse H. Turner, Negro, has filed suit against Memphis Public Library in the United States District Court here. At a meeting of the Directors of the library held yesterday a resolution was adopted, copy of which has been sent to the Mayor, requesting the City Commission at its next meeting to direct Mr. Frank B. Gianotti, City Attorney, and his legal staff to defend this action on behalf of all the defendants. We hope that the City Commission will grant this request. -- Cordially yours, -- President"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Randolph, Wassell
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Digital Image ©2012, Memphis Public Library & Information Center. All rights reserved. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: 1958-08-21 Loeb Correspondence
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: libraries; civil rights; desegregation; Randolph, Wassell; Loeb, Henry; 1950s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Copy of a letter sent by Wassell Randolph to Commissioner Loeb: "Dear Commissioner Loeb: -- You have read in the newspapers where Jesse H. Turner, Negro, has filed suit against Memphis Public Library in the United States District Court here. At a meeting of the Directors of the library held yesterday a resolution was adopted, copy of which has been sent to the Mayor, requesting the City Commission at its next meeting to direct Mr. Frank B. Gianotti, City Attorney, and his legal staff to defend this action on behalf of all the defendants. We hope that the City Commission will grant this request. -- Cordially yours, -- President"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Randolph, Wassell
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Digital Image ©2012, Memphis Public Library & Information Center. All rights reserved. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: 1961-09-06 Correspondence
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: law; libraries; civil rights; desegregation; Russell, Edward P.; Randolph, Wassell; 1960s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A letter from attorney Edward P. Russell to library board president Wassell Randolph: "The plaintiff's attorneys have not yet filed their statement of costs as required by the Federal Rules and may not do so for an indefinite time, if ever. Until filed there is no cost bill for the defendants to pay. Under the circumstances I think we should let the matter drift until plaintiff's attorneys take the appropriate action. -- Herewith, in blank, our statement for legal services. Please fix the amount thereof as you and your associates may think proper. -- I am greatly pleased to have been associated with you and the other Trustees in this litigation though the results were not as we would have liked for them to have been. -- Sincerely yours, Edward P. Russell"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Russell, Edward P.
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Digital Image ©2012, Memphis Public Library & Information Center. All rights reserved. While the Memphis Public Library & Information Center may house an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: 1961-05-08 Correspondence
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: law; libraries; civil rights; desegregation; Russell, Edward P.; Wallis, C. Lamar; 1960s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A letter from attorney Edward P. Russell to library director C. Lamar Wallis: "Thank you for your letter about our effort in the Library litigation. It is, of course, a losing effort, but we will continue to do whatever can be done. Your co-operation is much appreciated. -- Sincerely, Edward P. Russell"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Russell, Edward P.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: 1961-01-04 Correspondence
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: correspondence; libraries; civil rights; desegregation; Wallis, C. Lamar; Luening, Eugene A.; First Unitarian Church; 1960s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Dear Mr. West [sic], -- We have tried to find any information available concerning the use of rest rooms in public facilities in other southern communities, as you suggested in your letter of December 16th. [sic] to me as president of the local shapter [sic] of the Tennessee Council on Human Relations. -- We have written to the southern Regional Council. They had no information about this problem. They suggested a southern law reporting service. I do not have the reference for that organizations [sic] correct name and address; we are still looking! -- Sincerely, -- Eugene A. Luening"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Luening, Eugene A.
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Digital Image ©2012, Memphis Public Library & Information Center. All rights reserved. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: 1960-11-28 Correspondence
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: law; libraries; civil rights; desegregation; Russell, Edward P.; Creson, Larry; Montedonico, John S.; Randolph, Wassell; 1960s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A copy of a letter from library board president Wassell Randolph to attorneys Russell, Creson and Montedonico: "Gentlemen: -- The Board of Directors of Cossitt Library have resolved that in view of the city ordinance requiring separate rest room facilities to be provided for the races in public buildings they desire in the above case that you request of the court permission to amend the answer of the defendants and set up the city ordinance as an additional defense to this suit. The Board desires, if possible, to have this issue determined by the court on the evidence that can be introduced. -- Cordially yours, -- Wassell Randolph, President"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Randolph, Wassell
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Digital Image ©2012, Memphis Public Library & Information Center. All rights reserved. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: 1960-11-08 Correspondence
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: law; libraries; civil rights; desegregation; Wallis, C. Lamar; Gianotti, Frank; 1960s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A copy of a letter sent from Lamar Wallis to Frank Gianotti: "Dear Mr. Gianotti: -- As you requested by telephone today I have copied below the resolution of the Library Board concerning integration: -- At a special meeting of the Board of Trustees of Cossitt Library held September 9, 1960, called at the request of the City Commission for the purpose of reconsidering the long standing policy of this and previous Boards of maintaining segregated library facilities, and at which members of the City Commission were present, the following resolution was adopted: -- That the matter of changing the policy of the Memphis Public Library System be referred to the City Commission for decision. -- The Board of Trustees being now advised that the City Commission has decided that all units of the Library System be desegregated, the Board of Trustees now abides by that decision. -- Sincerely, -- C. Lamar Wallis -- Director"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Wallis, C. Lamar
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Digital Image ©2012, Memphis Public Library & Information Center. All rights reserved. Russell"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Papers Presented": presentation of the Elder Blair T. Hunt Papers
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Memphis Public Library & Information Center; Wallis, C. Lamar; Hunt, Blair T.; African Americans; history; local history; 1970s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Commercial Appeal news photo of Library Director C. Lamar Wallis, Dr. Hollis Price and Rheba Hoffman. Caption reads: "Lamar Wallis (left), director of the Memphis Public Library and Information Center, accepts the gift of the Elder Blair T. Hunt Papers last night from Dr. Hollis Price and Rheba Hoffman. Mr. Hunt, who was a Memphis educator and civic and religious leader, died at age 90 on July 26, 1978. The presentation of the papers marked the beginning of the library's Black History Month, with the theme, 'Hisstory: Torch for the Future.' The Commercial Appeal, Memphis, Friday, February 2, 1979."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dr. Joseph Riggs, C. Lamar Wallis, Craig Leake, and Norman Brewer
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Memphis Public Library & Information Center; Wallis, C. Lamar; television; WMC; Crump, E. H.;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Note on Back: "Receiving a Memphis Public Library copy of 'The Once and Always Mister Crump,' one-hour WMC-TV film documentary on the life of the late Memphis and Shelby County political leader E. H. Crump, are (1) Dr. Joseph Riggs, director of the Memphis and Shelby County Archives; and C. Lamar Wallis, director of Memphis Public Library. Presenting the film are Craig Leake (r. center), who produced and filmed the special; and WMC-TV News Director Norman Brewer, who narrated it. The Memphis Scripps-Howard station also presented the Archives with more than fifteen hours of sound-on-film interviews with politically prominent figures during the Crump era."
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Digital Image ©2014, Memphis Public Library & Information Center. All rights reserved. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Jack Cofield and Helen Karpinski
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Memphis Public Library & Information Center; books; Faulkner, William; Cofield, Jack; Karpinski, Mary Helen; books; programs; authors;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Note on Back: "September was a very busy 'Faulkner Festival' at Memphis/Shelby County Public Library and Information Center. Beginning with an extensive exhibit of Faulkner photographs, first editions and print collectibles along with an autograph party for Jack Cofield, author of a new photo-biography, the offerings also included films, slide talks, discussion of literary contribution, television and radio programs. Pictured here are Jack Cofield and Helen Karpinski of the Library's Films and Community TV Department."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Main Library - WTTL (2)
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Memphis Public Library & Information Center; West Tennessee Talking Library; Main Library; 1980s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Note on Back: "WTTL Logo. The West Tennessee Talking Library is a service of the Memphis/Shelby County Public Library and Information Center that transmits broadcasting to physically handicapped and blind residents within a 60 mile radius of Memphis. Any person who is unable to hold or read conventional printed material may borrow a special radio receiver to pick up information broadcast by WTTL. Volunteers give of their time to prepare and broadcast programs each week. They read local daily and weekly newspapers, magazines and best seller books or present programs such as interviews with people who supply vital human services. 1981"
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Digital Image ©2014, Memphis Public Library & Information Center. All rights reserved. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Poster of Robert Croneberger in Print Shop
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Memphis Public Library & Information Center; Croneberger, Robert; Main Library; 1980s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Poster with picture of Robert Croneberger: "Extra!! oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Library officials being shown about handicap awareness
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Memphis Public Library & Information Center; Main Library; Croneberger, Robert; Johnson, Sallie; disabilities; 1970s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Note on back: "In August of 1978 officials at Memphis Public Library join a rolling tour through Main Library conducted by the Tri-State Chapter of National Paraplegic Foundation. The tour was arranged to increase the awareness of library personnel to the problems encountered by the wheelchair bound patron. Several changes came from this experience, e.g. arrangement of furniture, parking and entry facilities. Those taking part included the Chairman of the Library's Board, Deputy Director, Business Manager and others."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Mr. Wallis, Ms. Harriet Fuller, and Mr. William F. Murrah
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Memphis Public Library & Information Center; Wallis, C. Lamar; Murrah, William F.; Fuller, Harriet; Cherokee Branch; buildings; libraries; 1970s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Note on back: "Dedication of Cherokee Branch Library, a $224,000 facility, was held on April 6, 1975. The 10,000 square foot building contains 15,000 books for all ages plus phonography records, cassettes, periodicals, newspapers and a meeting room for community use. In the photo, from left to right, are Ms. Harriett Fuller, Head Librarian; Lamar Wallis, Library Director and William F. Murrah, Chairman, Board of Trustees."

Not only can she check out materials for her knowledge or entertainment, but she can learn about the many story times, puppet shows and special programs for her children as they grow."
